ac:rich-text-body.p: Shibboleth is a standards based, open source software package for web single sign-on across or within organisational boundaries. It allows sites to make informed decisions for individual access of protected online resources in a privacy-preserving manner.

The Shibboleth software implements widely used federated identity standards, principally the OASIS Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML), to provide a federated single sign-on and attribute exchange framework. A user authenticates with his or her organizational credentials, and the organisation (or identity provider) passes the minimal identity information necessary to the service provider to enable an authorisation [is the user authorised to access the site] decision. Shibboleth also provides extended privacy functionality allowing a user and their home site to control the attributes released to each application.
Shibboleth IDP3 has been implemented as the identity provider (IdP) for all web-sso protected applications within the university.
The University of Auckland's web-sso provides seamless access to shared computing resources and collaboration environments provided through the Tuakiri access federation
The application is typically accessed via a login page when trying to access a protected application, but can be accessed directly from these locations:

Windows Server with Virtual Hosts to EPR Shibboleth

p.ac:placeholder: Remove this section for SaaS/Cloud application.

p.span:
Shibboleth
provides authentication for all Web SSO enabled applications. It does not provide for group-based authorisations. It is solely an authentication solution.

ac:rich-text-body.p: End users & anyone who is trying to log into an application that has SSO enabled

p.span:
3. Which affiliations and groups are used for access control?
There are neither affiliations, nor groups related to access control. SSO itself provides access control in the form of authentication.

strong.span: 4. What is the process for requestin

p.span: End user access to web-sso is provided upon registration (usually self-registation) to the

span.span: Web-SSO provides two levels of authentication

li.span: Level 2 - username and password. Provides the minimum level of authentication requiring username and password to access a resource.

Level 3 - two-step verification. Provides additional security by requiring a user to login by entering a one-time token in addition to username and password. Users are required to register for two factor authentication through the
mytoken
service.

span.em: Note: Level 0 and Level 1 are deprecated levels of authentication.

p.span:
A
solution has been developed to provide a seamless web-sso authentication solution for domain-connected users running the DSSO service. Once logged onto their computer, users are able to access web-sso protected resources without having to manually authenticate.

tr.td: Single Sign On, Web SSO, SSO, OneLogin, Shibboleth, Shibboleth IdP3.
